title: Leopard Gecko Lighting Guide: UVB & Photoperiod for Crepuscular Species
description: Complete lighting guide for leopard geckos covering low-level UVB requirements, albino morph considerations, photoperiod management, and the UVB vs dietary D3 debate.
author: Habitat Builder

content.title: Essential Lighting Requirements for Leopard Geckos
content.content: Leopard geckos are crepuscular (most active at dawn and dusk) with adaptations for low-light conditions. For years, they were kept without UVB lighting, relying on dietary vitamin D3 supplementation. However, modern research shows that leopard geckos benefit significantly from low-level UVB exposure, demonstrating improved bone density, appetite, and natural behaviors. This guide covers evidence-based lighting practices, including special considerations for albino and low-pigment morphs.
Leopard geckos receive indirect UVB in their natural habitat during crepuscular activity periods. They are classified as Ferguson Zone 2, requiring low-level UVB exposure.

content.text: UVB Requirements by Morph:

rows: Standard Ferguson Zone 2 recommendation for crepuscular species
Reduced melanin = increased UV sensitivity, risk of burns
Low pigment morphs more sensitive to UV radiation
Moderate pigmentation, slightly reduced UVB tolerance

content.content: Albino and patternless morphs CAN be burned by excessive UVB. Use lower UVI targets (0.5-0.7) and monitor for signs of UV overexposure: redness, swelling, blistering on skin, or avoidance of basking area. These morphs benefit from UVB but need reduced intensity.
Low-output linear fluorescent UVB bulbs are ideal for leopard geckos. Avoid high-output desert bulbs (10.0/12%) which provide excessive UVB.

content.text: Recommended UVB Bulbs (36×18×18 enclosure):

rows: Albino morphs with 14-16" distance from basking

content.content: Do NOT use: Mercury vapor bulbs (too intense), desert-strength 10.0/12% linear bulbs for normal morphs (excessive UVB), or any UVB without measuring with Solarmeter 6.5. The compact 10.0 recommendation for albinos is ONLY at 11-14" distance—closer causes burns.
UVB intensity decreases rapidly with distance (inverse square law). Proper placement ensures safe, effective exposure for different morphs.

content.content: Verification is essential: Use a Solarmeter 6.5 to measure UVI at basking area. Albino morphs showing signs of stress (hiding constantly, redness) may need UVI reduced to 0.3-0.5. Adjust distance until gecko uses basking area comfortably.
Beyond UVB, leopard geckos benefit from visible light that supports circadian rhythms and natural behaviors. Their crepuscular nature means they don't need intense lighting.

content.text: Lighting Options for Daytime:

rows: Provides basking heat + visible light (dual function)
Plant growth in bioactive, gentle ambient light
Acceptable if heat lamp provides some visible light

content.content: Leopard geckos don't need bright lights—they're adapted for twilight conditions. A heat lamp providing moderate visible light is sufficient. Avoid intense bright lights that cause stress and hiding behaviors.
Consistent day/night cycles regulate leopard gecko activity, feeding, and breeding behaviors. Use timers to automate lighting schedules.

content.text: Lighting Schedule:

rows: Active season, breeding period, peak feeding
Brumation preparation (optional for breeding), rest period
Natural activity peak at dusk/dawn, melatonin production

content.content: Do NOT use blue, red, or colored LED 'moonlights' at night. These disrupt circadian rhythms and suppress melatonin. Leopard geckos have excellent night vision—they don't need light to navigate. Complete darkness at night is essential.
Leopard geckos were historically kept without UVB using high-D3 calcium supplements. Research now shows UVB provides significant health benefits.

content.text: UVB vs D3 Supplementation Comparison:

rows: Adequate for survival, some deficiencies seen long-term

content.content: Modern consensus: Provide UVB for optimal health. Leopard geckos with UVB show improved appetite, stronger bones, and more natural behaviors. Albino morphs can still receive UVB benefits with reduced intensity (0.5-0.7 UVI).
UVB output degrades over time even though the bulb still produces visible light. Replace bulbs on schedule to maintain effective UVB levels.

content.text: Bulb Replacement Schedule:

rows: Compact coil UVB (if used for albinos)
Rapid degradation, inconsistent output over time
Stops working entirely when filament breaks
Gradual dimming, no UVB so less critical

content.content: Mark replacement dates on calendar or label bulbs with install date. UVB bulbs often look fine but have lost 40-50% output after 6-8 months (T8) or 12 months (T5). Don't wait for bulb to stop working—UVB degrades while visible light remains.

content.content: Albino, patternless, and hypomelanistic morphs require special lighting considerations due to reduced melanin protection.

content.text: Albino-Safe UVB Setup:

rows: Albinos don't show redness until burned—measure UVI
Allows gecko to avoid UVB while still accessing heat
Watch for avoidance behavior or redness
If gecko hides constantly or skin looks red, reduce UVI
Skip UVB entirely, use high-D3 supplements
Safe option if unable to achieve low UVI reliably

content.content: Albino morphs showing any redness, swelling, or constant avoidance of basking area are receiving too much UVB. Increase distance immediately or remove UVB. Burns can occur within 2-3 days of overexposure. Some individual albinos may not tolerate any UVB—monitor carefully.

content.text: Essential Lighting Equipment:

rows: 12-18" Zoo Med ReptiSun 5.0 T8 or Arcadia 6% T8
Low-level UVB (1.0-2.0 UVI) for vitamin D3
14-18" T8 hood with reflector OR compact socket
Houses UVB bulb, reflector increases efficiency
Digital plug-in timer (2x—one for UVB, one for heat)
Verify UVB levels for albino safety and normal gecko optimization

content.content: Initial lighting investment: $70-110 (UVB bulb + fixture + timer + heat lamp). Annual maintenance: $20-35 for bulb replacements. Solarmeter 6.5 ($200-250) is optional but strongly recommended for albino morphs to prevent burns.

rows: UVB too intense OR basking too hot
Measure UVI (should be 1.0-2.0 normal, 0.5-0.7 albino), check basking temp 94-97°F
Remove UVB immediately, increase distance to 14-16", or skip UVB and use D3 supplements
Heat lamp should provide moderate light, add low-intensity LED if needed
Add UVB if not provided (improves calcium metabolism), verify calcium supplementation
Replace fixture if old (ballasts degrade after 3-5 years)
Replace T5 at 12 months, T8 at 6-8 months even though bulb still lights
